prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 1st frequency setting: CH3CN, CH3OCHO, CH3CHO, and NH2CH2CN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The frequency setting is tuned to detect multiple transitions from CH3CN, CH3OCHO, CH3CHO, and NH2CH2CN (+ many others). The four 468 MHz wide spectral windows are centered at: 257.400, 258.326, 269.810, 272.660 GHz.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request a spectral resolution of 288 kHz, equal to 0.3 km/s in band 6 in four spectral windows of 468 MHz bandwidth.
Our proposal aims to detect a high number (> 300) of weak (12 - 200 mJy/beam) and relatively narrow (1.5 - 2 km/s) transitions. A compromise needs to be made between high spectral resolution and large bandwidth that allows us to spectrally resolve many transitions from the targeted species. A spectral resolution of 288 kHz, equal to 0.3 km/s at 260 GHz and resulting from a spectral hanning averaging of the 242 kHz spectral channels, is requested to resolve the transitions with about 5-6 spectral channels / line. The investigation of the line profile, possible with this spectral resolution, will allow us to investigate the contamination of the targeted lines from other transitions.
In order to get as many transitions from our targeted species in our spectral windows as possible, we chose to use four spectral windows of 468 MHz bandwidth (two spectral windows per sideband). The frequency setting has been optimized to have the highest possible line density from targeted species.

We request an angular resolution of 0.2 arcsec and a recoverable scale higher than 2.8 arcsec.
This proposal aims to spatially resolve the emission of complex organics originating from the inner regions of the protostellar envelope of tree of the brightest low-mass protostars. Transitions from complex organics are believed to emit in the inner regions of protostellar envelopes where interstellar ices thermal evaporate at T > 100 K. A one-dimension radiative transfer modelling of the targeted sources by Maret et al. (2004) suggests COM emission sizes of 0.4 arcsec in IRAS2A and IRAS4A and of 0.3 arcsec in IRAS4B. We consequently request an angular resolution of 0.2 arcsec that will allow us to resolve the emission of COMs in the three targeted protostars.
IRAS2A and IRAS4A are known to be binary systems, with separations of 1.8 and 0.6 arcsec, respectively. We request a recoverable angular scale of 2.80 arcsec, which is about 1.6 and 4.6 times the separation between the binary sources, in order to recover the whole emission of the targeted transitions from complex organics.
In band 6, the requested angular resolution of 0.2 arcsec and the recoverable scale of 2.8 arcsec can be achieved using only one configuration (C36-5).

We request a sensitivity of 4 mJy/beam per 282 kHz spectral channel.
The requested sensitivity is based on the predicted peak fluxes from transitions of the less abundant targeted species. For this purpose, we predicted the synthetic spectrum of the targeted sources through a LTE population modelling of the levels taking the opacities into account, assuming an excitation temperature equal to that of methanol (140 K), and using a linewidth of 2 km/s (Persson et 2012, Taquet et al. 2015). The column densities of abundant COMs, including methanol, have been taken from previous interferometric observations with the Plateau de Bure interferometer that allowed us to detect several transitions of each abundant COM but at a low angular resolution of 2 arcsec (Taquet et al. 2015). Abundances of less abundant COMs, not detected in solar-type protostars so far, have been estimated by scaling the abundance ratios with respect to methanol derived by Belloche et al. (2013) toward the massive protostellar cluster SgrB2(N), to the column density of methanol derived toward IRAS2A and IRAS4A.
The predicted fluxes range between 12 and 200 mJy/beam for a beam of 0.2 arcsec, but between 12 and 40 mJy/beam for the less abundant targeted species never detected low-mass protostars so far. We request a rms of 4 mJy/beam per 282 kHz spectral channel so we can be able to detect at least 10 transitions from all our targeted species, over a large range of upper energy levels, at a signal to noise ratio higher than 3. The multi-transition detection will allow us to map the column densities of COMs around the targeted sources.

The requested datarate of 12.21 MB/sec, slightly higher than the limit of 12 MB/sec, is needed to achieve the goal of our proposal since our proposal is based on the detection of a high number (> 300) of weak (12 - 200 mJy/beam) and relatively narrow (1.5 - 2 km/s) transitions. Both the use of four wide spectral windows (468 MHz) per frequency setting combined with a relatively high spectral resolution (288 kHz) are consequently needed.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 2nd frequency setting: HCOOH, 13-CH3CN, C2H5CN, and CH3OCH3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The frequency setting is tuned to detect multiple transitions from HCOOH, 13-CH3CN, C2H5CN, and CH3OCH3 (+ many others). The four 468 MHz wide spectral windows are centered at: 247.730, 249.860, 260.450, 263.470 GHz.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request a spectral resolution of 288 kHz, equal to 0.3 km/s in band 6 in four spectral windows of 468 MHz bandwidth.
Our proposal aims to detect a high number (> 300) of weak (12 - 200 mJy/beam) and relatively narrow (1.5 - 2 km/s) transitions. A compromise needs to be made between high spectral resolution and large bandwidth that allows us to spectrally resolve many transitions from the targeted species. A spectral resolution of 288 kHz, equal to 0.3 km/s at 260 GHz and resulting from a spectral hanning averaging of the 242 kHz spectral channels, is requested to resolve the transitions with about 5-6 spectral channels / line. The investigation of the line profile, possible with this spectral resolution, will allow us to investigate the contamination of the targeted lines from other transitions.
In order to get as many transitions from our targeted species in our spectral windows as possible, we chose to use four spectral windows of 468 MHz bandwidth (two spectral windows per sideband). The frequency setting has been optimized to have the highest possible line density from targeted species.

We request an angular resolution of 0.2 arcsec and a recoverable scale higher than 2.8 arcsec.
This proposal aims to spatially resolve the emission of complex organics originating from the inner regions of the protostellar envelope of tree of the brightest low-mass protostars. Transitions from complex organics are believed to emit in the inner regions of protostellar envelopes where interstellar ices thermal evaporate at T > 100 K. A one-dimension radiative transfer modelling of the targeted sources by Maret et al. (2004) suggests COM emission sizes of 0.4 arcsec in IRAS2A and IRAS4A and of 0.3 arcsec in IRAS4B. We consequently request an angular resolution of 0.2 arcsec that will allow us to resolve the emission of COMs in the three targeted protostars.
IRAS2A and IRAS4A are known to be binary systems, with separations of 1.8 and 0.6 arcsec, respectively. We request a recoverable angular scale of 2.80 arcsec, which is about 1.6 and 4.6 times the separation between the binary sources, in order to recover the whole emission of the targeted transitions from complex organics.
In band 6, the requested angular resolution of 0.2 arcsec and the recoverable scale of 2.8 arcsec can be achieved using only one configuration (C36-5).

We request a sensitivity of 4 mJy/beam per 282 kHz spectral channel.
The requested sensitivity is based on the predicted peak fluxes from transitions of the less abundant targeted species. For this purpose, we predicted the synthetic spectrum of the targeted sources through a LTE population modelling of the levels taking the opacities into account, assuming an excitation temperature equal to that of methanol (140 K), and using a linewidth of 2 km/s (Persson et 2012, Taquet et al. 2015). The column densities of abundant COMs, including methanol, have been taken from previous interferometric observations with the Plateau de Bure interferometer that allowed us to detect several transitions of each abundant COM but at a low angular resolution of 2 arcsec (Taquet et al. 2015). Abundances of less abundant COMs, not detected in solar-type protostars so far, have been estimated by scaling the abundance ratios with respect to methanol derived by Belloche et al. (2013) toward the massive protostellar cluster SgrB2(N), to the column density of methanol derived toward IRAS2A and IRAS4A.
The predicted fluxes range between 12 and 200 mJy/beam for a beam of 0.2 arcsec, but between 12 and 40 mJy/beam for the less abundant targeted species never detected low-mass protostars so far. We request a rms of 4 mJy/beam per 282 kHz spectral channel so we can be able to detect at least 10 transitions from all our targeted species, over a large range of upper energy levels, at a signal to noise ratio higher than 3. The multi-transition detection will allow us to map the column densities of COMs around the targeted sources.

Our proposal aims to detect a high number (> 300) of weak (12 - 200 mJy/beam) and relatively narrow (1.5 - 2 km/s) transitions. Both the use of four wide spectral windows (468 MHz) per frequency setting combined with a relatively high spectral resolution (288 kHz) are needed to achieve the goals of the proposal. This results in a datarate of 12.21 MB/sec, which is slightly higher than the limit of 12 MB/sec.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The early stages of star formation are known to be rich in Complex Organic Molecules (COMs). Intriguing spatial and abundance differentiations, and in particular between nitrogen and oxygen species, have been observed around high-mass protostars. Similar chemical differentiations have been noticed toward only one low-mass protobinary system so far and for a few COMs only. This proposal aims to carry out a census of the chemical differentiations of COMs that are believed to occur in solar-type protostars, on scales as small as a few tens of AU. Using a high spatial resolution of 0.2 arcsec, only achievable with ALMA, we aim to spatially resolve the multi-line emission of different families of COMs around three of the brightest solar-type protostellar systems located in the NGC1333 star-forming region. These observations will also result in the first detection of several COMs of prebiotic interest in solar-type protostars. The comparison of their spatial extent and of their abundance will allow us to constrain the different scenarios invoked to explain the formation and destruction of COMs but also to retrace the physical and chemical history of the observed protostars.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Goddard Space Flight Center, National Aeronautics and Space Administration
Laboratoire Interuniversitaire des systemes atmospheriques, Universite Paris Est
Radiospectrometry department, Institute of Radio Astronomy of NASU
